docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 3 GENERAL RULES ABOUT GIVING EVIDENCE [ss 26–36]

heading.title: DIVISION 3 GENERAL RULES ABOUT GIVING EVIDENCE [ss 26–36]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 3 GENERAL RULES ABOUT GIVING EVIDENCE [ss 26–36]
[50,230] s 26 Court's control over questioning of witnesses

leg:heading.title: Court's control over questioning of witnesses

p.text: The court may make such orders as it considers just in relation to:
the way in which witnesses are to be questioned, and
the production and use of documents and things in connection with the questioning of witnesses, and
the order in which parties may question a witness, and
the presence and behaviour of any person in connection with the questioning of witnesses.
ALRC 38 paras 107–108.

level.toc-caption: [50,230.10] Control over the conduct of proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,230.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 29.5.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 61.

heading.title: Control over the conduct of proceedings

p.text: The section confirms the court's power to control the conduct of hearings. The procedure for conduct of trials is provided for in UCPR r 29.5 . See the detailed notes and cross references, particularly to the court’s detailed directions power in CPA s 61 , which commence at [29.5.5] .

level.toc-caption: [50,230.15] Examination of witnesses by the court

heading.title: Examination of witnesses by the court

p.text: The Act does not affect the common law position in relation to the calling and examination of witnesses by the court. The matter is discussed in [29.5.100] . As to the questioning of witnesses by the jury (and comments on its undesirability) see R v Pathare [1981] 1 NSWLR 124; R v Lo Presti [1992] 1 VR 696.
A party may question any witness, except as provided by this Act.
ALRC 38 para 111(a)

level.toc-caption: [50,235.10] The right of parties to examine witnesses

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,235.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 26.

heading.title: The right of parties to examine witnesses

p.text: This section, when read with s 26 , suggests that most, if not all, of the established practices in relation to the questioning of witnesses are of continued relevance under the Evidence Act 1995. For example the restriction on the examination of witnesses by multiple counsel for the same party is still relevant. However, by conferring an express right of examination on any party, the section may alter the rule of practice that there should be only one cross-examination by parties who are in the same interest: GPI Leisure Corp Ltd v Herdsman Investments Pty Ltd (No 3) (1990) 20 NSWLR 15 at 23 . [See the notes at [29.5.5] .

level.toc-caption: [50,235.15] Except as provided by this Act

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,235.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 40.

heading.title: Except as provided by this Act

p.text: There is no right to cross-examine a witness who has been sworn in error and has not given any relevant evidence: see s 40 below.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,240] s 28 Order of examination in chief, cross-examination and re-examination

leg:heading.title: Order of examination in chief, cross-examination and re-examination

p.text: Unless the court otherwise directs:
cross-examination of a witness is not to take place before the examination in chief of the witness, and
re-examination of a witness is not to take place before all other parties who wish to do so have cross-examined the witness.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,245] s 29 Manner and form of questioning witnesses and their responses

leg:heading.title: Manner and form of questioning witnesses and their responses

p.text: A party may question a witness in any way the party thinks fit, except as provided by this Chapter or as directed by the court.
A court may, on its own motion or on the application of the party that called the witness, direct that the witness give evidence wholly or partly in narrative form.
[subs (2) subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[9], effective 1 January 2009]
Such a direction may include directions about the way in which evidence is to be given in that form.

Evidence may be given in the form of charts, summaries or other explanatory material if it appears to the court that the material would be likely to aid its comprehension of other evidence that has been given or is to be given.
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 281, 607–608, 609
ALRC 38 para 111(c)
ALRC 102 paras 5.6–5.36

The expression "narrative form" is not defined in the Act. The intention is to distinguish it from evidence given in response to specific questions. Presumably, the basic reason for the permission to give evidence in narrative form is to increase the fluency and reliability of evidence in chief, particularly in relation to expert evidence. However, the permission is not confined to evidence in chief. Relevant considerations in the exercise of the power include the witness’ age, cultural background and ability to observe warnings about what evidence is admissible. Even where a direction has been given allowing a witness to give evidence in narrative form, the court retains the power to either revoke the direction, or to require a witness to answer particular questions with a direct response.

There is no rule of law which renders evidence of a conversation inadmissible unless it is given in direct speech. It may be appropriate to require oral evidence to be given in direct speech in order to provide a proper opportunity to test the accuracy and reliability of the witness’ recollection on a material matter: see LMI Australasia Pty Ltd v Baulderstone Hornibrook Pty Ltd (2001) 53 NSWLR 31; [2001] NSWSC 688; BC200104748 .

The section provides specific statutory authority for the practice of allowing charts and summaries to be used as aids to the understanding of the primary evidence in the proceedings: R v Tucker (1907) SALR 30; Smith v R (1970) 121 CLR 572 at 577; [1971] ALR 193 ; R v Simmons [1969] 1 QB 685 at 690; R v Menzies [1982] 1 NZLR 40. The section expressly allows the explanatory charts etc to be tendered before the primary evidence, but makes clear that the explanatory material is wholly dependent upon the ultimate admission of the evidence to which it relates: see Alucraft Pty Ltd (in liq) v Grocon Ltd (No 1) [1996] 2 VR 377; BC9300981 .

A witness may give evidence about a fact through an interpreter unless the witness can understand and speak the English language sufficiently to enable the witness to understand, and to make an adequate reply to, questions that may be put about the fact.
ALRC 26 Vol 1 paras 282–285, 610–611
ALRC 38 paras 111(d), 1112(a)

The section alters the previous common law position by expressly providing that a witness has a right to give evidence through an interpreter. However, the right is conditional upon the witness's lack of sufficient understanding of English. The question of witness's capacity to understand English is a matter for the trial judge to assess. It may be, therefore, that the present section will, in most cases, not significantly alter the position that would have applied under the previous law which acknowledged the trial judge's discretion to allow the use of an interpreter whenever it was necessary for the witness to give evidence effectively: Adamopoulos v Olympic Airways SA (1991) 25 NSWLR 75 ; Dairy Farmers Co-op Milk Co Ltd v Acquilina (1963) 109 CLR 458; [1964] ALR 333 .
A witness who cannot hear adequately may be questioned in any appropriate way.
A witness who cannot speak adequately may give evidence by any appropriate means.
The court may give directions concerning either or both of the following:
the way in which a witness may be questioned under subsection (1) ,
the means by which a witness may give evidence under subsection (2) .
This section does not affect the right of a witness to whom this section applies to give evidence about a fact through an interpreter under section 30 .
ALRC 26 Vol 1 para 612

It is generally desirable that, so far as possible, the witness's evidence be given orally: R v Hutton (1932) 49 WN (NSW) 91; (1932) 32 SR (NSW) 282 at 287 . (The reasons for the general desirability of oral evidence, particularly in criminal proceedings, is referred to in Butera v DPP (Vic) (1987) 164 CLR 180 at 189–90; 76 ALR 45; BC8701825 .)

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,260] s 32 Attempts to revive memory in court

leg:heading.title: Attempts to revive memory in court

p.text: A witness must not, in the course of giving evidence, use a document to try to revive his or her memory about a fact or opinion unless the court gives leave.
Without limiting the matters that the court may take into account in deciding whether to give leave, it is to take into account:
whether the witness will be able to recall the fact or opinion adequately without using the document, and
whether so much of the document as the witness proposes to use is, or is a copy of, a document that:
was written or made by the witness when the events recorded in it were fresh in his or her memory, or
was, at such a time, found by the witness to be accurate.

If a witness has, while giving evidence, used a document to try to revive his or her memory about a fact or opinion, the witness may, with the leave of the court, read aloud, as part of his or her evidence, so much of the document as relates to that fact or opinion.
The court is, on the request of a party, to give such directions as the court thinks fit to ensure that so much of the document as relates to the proceeding is produced to that party.
ALRC 26 Vol 1 paras 286–9, 614–15
ALRC 38 paras 111(e) and 112(b)
Legislation cited in [50,260.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 cl 6.
The term “document” is defined in the Dictionary . The circumstances in which a document is to be taken as having been “made” by a witness are referred to in cl 6 of Pt 2 of the Dictionary.
Legislation cited in [50,260.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 32(2).

The court may give leave for a witness to attempt to revive recollection by referring to a document. The matters that can be taken into account in granting leave include those in s 32(2) . The power to grant leave to attempt to revive memory in this way is generally consistent with the previous common law position. It is not necessary that the witness should totally exhaust recollection before being allowed to refer to the document: R v Baffigo [1957] VR 303 at 303–4 . And other parties may be afforded an opportunity to cross-examine as to whether the matters in s 32(2) have been made out: Hetherington v Brooks [1963] SASR 321 .

level.toc-caption: [50,260.20] Documents made or approved by the witness

heading.title: Documents made or approved by the witness

p.text: It is not necessary that the document used in an attempt to revive recollection should have been made by the witness. It is sufficient if the witness found the document to be accurate: Groves v Redbart [1975] Crim LR 158; R v Bass [1953] 1 QB 681 (notes prepared in collaboration); Gorman v Newton [1958] Qd R 169 (notes prepared by another person); Burrough v Martin (1809) 2 Camp 112. It is not necessary that the witness was aware of, and approved, the document when it was made. It is sufficient if the witness found the document to be accurate at any time when the events that it records were fresh in the witness's memory: R v Mills [1962] 3 All ER 298; Dyer v Best (1866) 4 H & C 189.

There was some debate in the common law authorities as to whether the document relied on to refresh memory had to have been prepared contemporaneously with (ie, within a reasonable time after) the events that it records: R v Simmonds [1967] 3 All ER 399; R v Richardson [1971] 2 QB 484 at 490. The section has no requirement of contemporaneity. It is sufficient if the document is made or approved when the events are fresh in the memory of the witness: R v Van Beelen (1972) 4 SASR 594 at 537. On the other hand, lack of close contemporaneity will make it more difficult to show that the events were fresh in the witness's recollection. A representation cannot ordinarily be regarded as "fresh in the memory" unless it is close in time to the events in question. The expression "fresh in the memory" does not mean just that the fact has been remembered, and certainly does not mean just "recently remembered": Graham v R (1998) 195 CLR 606; 157 ALR 404; [1998] HCA 61; BC9804990 .
Legislation cited in [50,260.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 32(3).

The conditional entitlement in s 32(3) , to read the relevant part of the document into evidence, is no doubt directed to the situation where the witness has little or no recollection of events, and there is a question whether the document is being used as a record of the events, rather than as a document that revives an actual memory of events: Ex parte Bennett; Re Cunningham (1967) 86 WN (Pt 2) (NSW) 323 at 333 ; Trade Practices Commission v TNT Management Pty Ltd (1984) 56 ALR 647 at 682 and contrast R v Bryant (1946) 31 Cr App R 146 and R v Harvey Jones (1979) 5 Petty SR 2059. The subsection allows the document that has been used to revive memory to be read as part of a witness's evidence.

level.toc-caption: [50,260.35] Production of documents used to revive memory

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,260.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 32(4).

heading.title: Production of documents used to revive memory

p.text: Section 32(4) continues the common law position that a party was entitled to require the production of documents that had been used to refresh memory in court: Beech v Jones (1848) 5 CB 696; R v Naidanovici [1962] NZLR 334 . (This entitlement applied to expert witnesses who have greater freedom in respect of the documents to which they may resort for the purpose of refreshing memory). However, it appears not to be confined to the use of documents in court and also applies to the documents used by witness in preparation for giving evidence: Lindsay-Owen v Lake [2000] NSWSC 1046; BC200006851 ; Lowe v Lang [2000] NSWSC 309; BC200001922 at [7] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,265] s 33 Evidence given by police officers

p.text: Despite section 32 in any criminal proceeding, a police officer may give evidence in chief for the prosecution by reading or being led through a written statement previously made by the police officer.
Evidence may not be so given unless:
the statement was made by the police officer at the time of or soon after the occurrence of the events to which it refers, and
the police officer signed the statement when it was made, and
a copy of the statement had been given to the person charged or to his or her Australian legal practitioner or legal counsel a reasonable time before the hearing of the evidence for the prosecution.
[subs (2) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[10], effective 1 January 2009]
A reference in this section to a police officer includes a reference to a person who, at the time the statement concerned was made, was a police officer.
Section 33(2)(c) is a notification provision for the purposes of Sch 2 Pt 2 cl 3(1) of the Evidence Act 1995, reproduced at [51,865] .

Section 33 is a recognition of the fact that police officers are frequently required to give evidence long after the relevant events have occurred and that in the intervening period, they may be likely to have been involved in a multiplicity of incidents about which they may also be required to testify at some future time. The section provides a transparent practice of evidencing matters that would be fresh in the memory of the Police officer at the time of making the statement, and vests in the Trial Judge a discretion to permit the procedure set out in the section to be followed in a particular case: see Chisari v R (No 2) [2006] NSWCCA 325; BC200608168 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,270] s 34 Attempts to revive memory out of court

leg:heading.title: Attempts to revive memory out of court

p.text: The court may, on the request of a party, give such directions as are appropriate to ensure that specified documents and things used by a witness otherwise than while giving evidence to try to revive his or her memory are produced to the party for the purposes of the proceeding.

The court may refuse to admit the evidence given by the witness so far as it concerns a fact as to which the witness so tried to revive his or her memory if, without reasonable excuse, the directions have not been complied with.
ALRC 26 para 26
ALRC 38 para 111(f)
The term “document” is defined in the Dictionary .

Under the common law a witness who, before giving evidence, attempted to refresh recollection from a document, was obliged to produce it for inspection by the parties: R v Pachonick [1973] 2 NSWLR 86. The obligation to produce seemed to depend upon whether a genuine (that is, independent) recollection had been refreshed or whether the witness relied wholly upon the document: R v Pachonick above; cf R v Bryant [1956] St R Qd 570 at 578 ; R v Alexander [1975] VR 741 at 749 ; Mancorp Pty Ltd v Baulderstone Pty Ltd (1991) 57 SASR 87 at 88–9 . However, the distinction between the two situations seems overly subtle. In using the expression “revive” rather than “refresh” memory, the section applies to both situations: Spalding v Radio Canberra Pty Ltd (2009) 166 ACTR 14; [2009] ACTSC 26; BC200901770 at [24]–[28] . The section assumes the existence of the parties' right to insist on production of any document, or other thing, that has been used to revive memory in question and provides a mechanism for the court to ensure its enforcement.

level.toc-caption: [50,270.3A] Documents used for the purpose of preparing affidavit evidence

heading.title: Documents used for the purpose of preparing affidavit evidence

p.text: The section applies to require the production of documents used by a witness for the purpose of reviving recollection in the course of preparing affidavit evidence: Lowe v Lang [2000] NSWSC 309; BC200001922 .

level.toc-caption: [50,270.20] Loss of privilege — obligation to produce

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,270.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 122(6).

heading.title: Loss of privilege — obligation to produce

p.text: If a document is used to revive out of court memory, it can be required to be produced under this section. Any privilege that would otherwise attach to the document does not prevent it being put into evidence: s 122(6) of the Act. See also [51,090.15] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,275] s 35 Effect of calling for production of documents

leg:heading.title: Effect of calling for production of documents

p.text: A party is not to be required to tender a document only because the party, whether under this Act or otherwise:
called for the document to be produced to the party, or
inspected it when it was so produced.
The party who produces a document so called for is not entitled to tender it only because the party to whom it was produced, or who inspected it, fails to tender it.
ALRC 26 Vol 1 paras 290–1, 617
ALRC 38 para 111(g)
Legislation cited in [50,275.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1898 s 12.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 12, ss 35, 36(3).

As a result of statutory provisions such as s 12 of the Evidence Act 1898 and perhaps the common law rules relating to the use of documents to refresh recollection, there was a practice whereby parties could call for production of a document in the possession of opposing parties (see for example, R v Pachonick [1973] 2 NSWLR 86 at 87 citing R v Skalij (NSWCCA, 23 June 1972, unreported)). The precise nature of the obligation that a call imposed was not settled by authority. Certainly a failure to produce was regarded as allowing secondary evidence of the contents of the document: Dwyer v Collins (1852) 7 Exch 639; 155 ER 1104; Morgan v Babcock and Wilcox Ltd (1929) 43 CLR 163 at 172; 35 ALR 313; 3 ALJR 234 ; and as preventing the non-producing party from thereafter relying upon the document: Doe d Hobbs v Cockell (1834) 6 C & P 525 at 528; 172 ER 138; Doe d Thompson v Hodgson (1840) 12 AD & E 135; 113 ER 762; Edmonds v Challis (1849) 7 CB 413; 137 ER 164. In H H Glass, Seminars on Evidence, Law Book Co, 1970, at p 13, Moffitt J suggested that the correct view was that there was no obligation to produce the document called for to an opponent but merely an obligation to produce the document to the court if an order was made for its production: see also O'Born v Cmr for Government Transport (1959) 77 WN (NSW) 81. In his Honour's view, the practice of producing documents in response to a “proper” call, merely acknowledged the likelihood that the court would ordinarily be expected to make an order for production under s 12 where the document called for was properly identified and apparently relevant to the proceedings. Irrespective of the basis of the obligation to produce, ss 35 and 36(3) ensure that there is no obligation to tender the documents produced in response to the call.

level.toc-caption: [50,275.15] Abolition of the rule in Walker v Walker

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,275.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 36(3).

heading.title: Abolition of the rule in Walker v Walker

p.text: The section makes clear that a party who calls for the production of a document is under no obligation to tender it. The section applies whatever the basis of the demand or request for production. The section (both on its own and with s 36(3) of the Act) effectively abolishes the contrary rule that was approved in Walker v Walker (1937) 57 CLR 630; 11 ALJR 201 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,280] s 36 Person may be examined without subpoena or other process

leg:heading.title: Person may be examined without subpoena or other process

p.text: The court may order a person who:
is present at the hearing of a proceeding, and
is compellable to give evidence in the proceeding,
to give evidence and to produce documents or things even if a subpoena or other process requiring the person to attend for that purpose has not been duly served on the person.
A person so ordered to give evidence or to produce documents or things is subject to the same penalties and liabilities as if the person had been duly served with such a subpoena or other process.
A party who inspects a document or thing produced to the court because of subsection (1) need not use the document in evidence.
Legislation cited in [50,280.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1898 s 12.

The section is substantially derived from previous statutory provisions that rendered a person present at the hearing of proceedings compellable to give evidence, or produce documents, without the need for prior service of a subpoena: for example, s 12 of the Evidence Act 1898.
Legislation cited in [50,280.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 33, r 33.9.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 183.

The powers of the court in relation to subpoenas are dealt with in UCPR Pt 33 . Both the powers conferred by that Part and by this section deal with the production of documents to the court. Thereafter, the question of inspection of the documents by the parties is a matter for the discretion of the court: National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Waind [1978] 1 NSWLR 372; Commissioner for Railways v Small (1938) 38 SR (NSW) 564 at 574; 55 WN (NSW) 215 ; Maddison v Goldrick [1976] 1 NSWLR 651 at 661–2 (inspection of the document must be sought for some legitimate forensic purpose); Attorney-General (NSW) v Findlay (1976) 9 ALR 521; 50 ALJR 637 (statements of witnesses at a committal hearing). As to the court's power to inspect documents in order to decide objections to production and admissibility see s 183 of the Act, r 33.9 and the notes at [33.9.5] .
